source.author: Walsh, N.G.; Albrecht, D.E.
source.title: Pittosporaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Walsh, N.G.; Albrecht, D.E. (1996). Pittosporaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves, branchlets and capsules glabrous (sometimes minutely pubescent when very young)
Leaves (at least the undersurfaces), branchlets and capsules conspicuously pubescent
Leaves narrow-linear, to 1 cm wide (often much less), margins plane; slender shrub of north and west, usually with pliant, drooping branches
Leaves lanceolate, elliptic or oblanceolate, mostly 2 cm wide or more, margins usually undulate; spreading shrubs or small trees
Flowers solitary in leaf axils or in small axillary cymes; petals maroon to blackish; leaves up to 6 cm long
Flowers in terminal umbel-like cymes or panicles; petals white, cream or yellow; leaves usually more than 6 cm long
Inflorescence usually paniculate; petals yellowish, to c. 7 mm long; sepals c. 2 mm long; capsule 5–6 mm long
Inflorescence of 1–several simple, stalked umbels; petals white, 8–17 mm long; sepals 5–10 mm long; capsule c. 1 cm long
Hairs of young growth red-brown; leaves finally glabrous or almost so, mostly more than 25 mm wide; flowers yellow; uncommon, rather sparse, spreading shrub of East Gippsland
Hairs white or greyish; leaves retaining pubescence on lower surface at maturity, not wider than 25 mm; flowers yellow, streaked maroon, or entirely maroon
Leaves narrowly obovate to oblanceolate, notably thick-textured; petals wholly maroon; capsule usually c. 20 mm diam; occasional shrub of coastal scrubs, escaped from cultivation
Leaves oblong or narrowly elliptic, not particularly thick-textured; petals yellow internally; capsule to c. 10 mm diam; shrub or tree of cool, moist, often upland forests
